titleStmt.title: Letter from Thomas Campbell to Henry, Lord Cockburn

body.p:
I have too much reliance on your
antientancient friendship to make you any long apology
for introducing to you a young English friend to
whom any casual attention you can pay will be doing
me a gratifying kindness―This will be delivered to you
by Mʳ Adams the son of Commissioner Adams―He is a
young man intended for the church of the most respectable + amiable character―I have known his family since he was
born—& I think it but right in commending him to your
friendship as he passes through Edingh to mention that
I introduce him not as a common acquaintance but
as a person in whose happiness I am very much interested.
He + his family are Tories but in spite of this I have
been on terms of mutual regard with them for three
generations—The young man himself has something
in his nature that will now allow him to be an
illiberal & therefore I like to introduce him among
the Whigs—as I believe that intercourse with them
will insensibly conciliate & alter his hereditary feelings
in polities—

I have not forgot your kindess in interfer­
­ing with Wardlaw—It did much good—I trust this
will find you + yours all well—I remain

closer.signed:
My dear Cockburn
with very warm + old recollections
yours truly T. Campbell

postscript.p:
P.S. Will you permit me to include in my introduction
Mʳ Barber the College Companion + fellow travel­
­er of Mʳ Adams—
